initial.narrative: A patient which is <%Patient.hasAge.Age%> presents with <%Patient.undergoesExamination.Wheeze%> <%Patient.undergoesExamination.Breathing-Condition%> <%Patient.givesHistory.Cough%>. What is the possible diagnosis?
initial.explanation: Wheeze together with either difficulty breathing or history of cough are symptoms of asthma.

severity.narrative: On examination of a patient with possible asthma, you find <%Patient.undergoesExamination.Oxygen-Saturation%> <%Patient.undergoesExamination.Central-Cyanosis%> <%Patient.undergoesExamination.Inability-To-Drink%> <%Patient.undergoesExamination.Consciousness%> <%Patient.undergoesExamination.Inability-To-Talk%> <%Patient.undergoesExamination.Pulse-Rate%> <%Patient.undergoesExamination.Lower-Chest-Wall-Indrawing%> <%Patient.undergoesExamination.Respiratory-Rate%>
severity.explanation:
SEVERE ASTHMA:
Oxygen saturation <90%,
central cyanosis,
inability to drink,
AVPU = V, P or U,
inability to talk,
pulse rate > 200 bpm (0-3 years) and >180 bpm (4-5 years).

MILD or MODERATE ASTHMA: 
wheeze 
PLUS 
lower chest wall indrawing
OR
RR => 50/min (2-11months)
RR =>40/min (12-59months)
RR=>30/min (5-12years)

management.narrative: You make a diagnosis of <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasSeverity.Severity%> <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasDiagnosisName.DiagnosisName%>. What of the following is the correct to do?
management.explanation: A patient with a severe asthma should be admitted into the hospital. For mild or moderate, don't admit.

prednisolone.narrative: A patient which is <%Patient.hasAge.Age%> and weighs <%Patient.hasWeight.Weight%> is diagnosed with <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasSeverity.Severity%> <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasDiagnosisName.DiagnosisName%>. What dose of prednisolone should be administered?
prednisolone.explanation:
A patient with a severe asthma should be given 2mg/kg. Max dose of 20mg/day for <2 years and 30mg/day for 2-5 years. Prednisolone should be administered for 3-5 days. 

Don't give prednisolone to patients with mild or moderate asthma.

nebulizer.narrative: What dose of <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasManagement.Management.involvesMedication.Salbutamol%> should be used in a <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasManagement.Management.involvesMedication.Salbutamol.hasRoute.Salbutamol-Route.hasMethod.Salbutamol-Method%>r?
nebulizer.explanation: 2.5mg salbutamol should be used in the nebulizer. It is is the same dose whether the asthma is severe, moderate or mild.

ipratopium-bromide.narrative: The patient you treat for <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasSeverity.Severity%> <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasDiagnosisName.DiagnosisName%> responds poorly to salbutamol. What is the next step?
ipratopium-bromide.explanation: Patients with severe asthma always gets administered with oxygen, salbutamol and prednisolone. If the response is poorly, administer ipratopium bromide.

ipratopium-bromide-2.narrative: What what is the right administration of <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasManagement.Management.involvesMedication.Ipratopium-Bromide%>?
ipratopium-bromide-2.explanation: Correct administration of ipratopium bromide is 250mcg every 20 minutes for 60 minutes. Use only when patient responds poorly to basic treatment.

antibiotics.narrative: The patient you treat for <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasSeverity.Severity%> <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasDiagnosisName.DiagnosisName%> is showing signs of severe pneumonia. What do you do?
antibiotics.explanation: For severe pneumonia administer antibiotics. Refer to the pneumonia guideline and antibiotic guideline.

basic-treatment.narrative: What is the right treatment to start with for <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasSeverity.Severity%> <%Patient.hasDiagnosis.Diagnosis.hasDiagnosisName.DiagnosisName%>?
basic-treatment.explanation: For all asthma treatment start with giving oxygen and salbutamol. Provide prednisolone for severe asthma.
